To accommodate message size constraints, I've limited the list to the top 100 non-ASCII characters. However, it's noteworthy to mention that in total, there are 314 distinct non-ASCII characters, each occurring in at least two separate Lean files within the Mathlib repository (limiting the analysis to the Mathlib/ directory).

(For clarity, the term "ASCII" used above refers to the extended ASCII character set.)
that is crazy that -> is used less than constructor notation
I was surprised at that too, then I understood why: we just move everything before colon.
I guess also it's just counting files, not occurrences?
I would expect there to be more occurrences of constructor notation than ->, since -> shows up mainly in theorem statements while constructor notation shows up in proofs
in particular in rcases
Does the ranking change if you count total uses rather than total number of files with uses?

Does this distribution of symbol usage align with your expectations?

I was very surprised to see alpha so low in the other list but now I understand why :-) (it has been expunged from lots of mathy files but there are these gigantic foundational files where it dominates)
‚Üí is now in its rightful place too
The fact that ‚ÇÇ outnumbers ‚ÇÅ suggests we are lazy at numbering
does the same apply for ‚ÇÅ dominating ‚ÇÄ? :-) (I thought you guys started at 0?)

Eric Wieser said:

The fact that ‚ÇÇ outnumbers ‚ÇÅ suggests we are lazy at numbering

I think this is probably due to constants and theorems containing ‚ÇÇ, such as docs#CategoryTheory.HasForget‚ÇÇ

In this analysis, I aimed to identify the "distinctive notation usage" within each directory of Mathlib.

Subsequently, from these results, I excluded any symbols that were also prevalent in the top 10 notations used across the entire Mathlib project. This approach allowed for highlighting the unique symbolic preferences characteristic to each specific directory.
